title: AB 2133
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature of California prioritizes improving occupational health and safety for family child care providers to ensure a safer environment for both providers and the children under their care. Family child care providers face occupational health and safety hazards such as toxic chemicals, illness, stress, and physical strain. They have musculoskeletal injury rates similar to industrial workers. Since they lack workers' compensation insurance, it is crucial for them and the children in their care to receive proper training to prevent injuries and illnesses on the job. The director must annually publish a list of licensed child day care facilities, excluding small family day care homes, detailing their services and licensed capacity. The department must protect the privacy of small family day care homes by not including their names and addresses on the lists. The director must annually publish a list of licensed child day care facilities, excluding small family day care homes, detailing their services and licensed capacity. Small family day care homes' names and addresses are protected for privacy, except for specific purposes like licensing administration and child placement facilitation. Names and addresses may be shared with certain agencies funded by the State Department of Education and other relevant programs. The entity selected to provide trainings required by Section 1596.864 includes family day care organizations and specialized health care service plans licensed under the Knox-Keene Health Care Service Plan Act of 1975. They offer employee assistance program services with child care referral services. Parents seeking local day care services can receive names and telephone numbers of local small family day care providers upon request. The department, in consultation with the Child Development Division of the State Department of Education, will adopt regulations for the confidentiality of information on small family day care homes. These regulations will ensure referral only to licensed homes in good standing. Violators may be denied access to information and reported to appropriate departments. Section 1596.864 of the Health and Safety Code defines a family child care provider as either a licensed family day care home provider or a person providing child care under a publicly funded program, excluding relatives of the children in care. A publicly funded child care program subsidizes early learning and care for children, administered by various state departments or agencies, excluding the K-12 public education system. A family child care provider must attend a two-hour training on occupational health and safety risks specific to the child care profession to protect their own health and safety and that of the children in their care. The State Department of Social Services requires family child care providers to complete training within four years or three months of becoming a provider. The training prioritizes licensed providers and covers risks like chemical and biological hazards. The training sessions for family child care providers cover risks such as chemical and biological hazards, infectious diseases, and physical hazards. It includes small and large group discussions and learning from current child care professionals. The training sessions for family child care providers cover risks including chemical and biological hazards, infectious diseases, and physical hazards. It involves small and large group discussions, learning from current child care professionals, and presentations by organizations focused on improving the child care system. The Department of Industrial Relations will select an entity through a competitive process to provide training for family child care providers. The training will cover various risks and include presentations by organizations focused on improving the child care system. Providers will also have an opportunity to give feedback on the training they receive. The Department of Industrial Relations will select an entity through a competitive process to provide occupational health and safety training for family child care providers. The selected entity must have experience in this training, train providers to give the required training to others, and provide updates on health and safety matters to trained providers. The selected entity for occupational health and safety training for family child care providers must have experience in training, train providers to give required training to others, and provide updates on health and safety matters to trained providers. The entity will develop the curriculum for training sessions with input from providers, which will be reviewed and approved by the Division of Occupational Safety and Health. The entity selected for occupational health and safety training for family child care providers will develop the curriculum for training sessions with input from providers, which will be reviewed and approved by the Division of Occupational Safety and Health. The State Department of Social Services will administer the contract for the training. The training will be coordinated with other preservice training requirements and resource networks to reduce the burden on providers. The department will provide lists of family child care providers who have attended training and those who still need to attend, along with their contact information, to the training entity monthly. The entity will use this information to update providers on health and safety issues. Providers can request to have their home address and telephone number removed from the lists before they are released. The department and the training entity must comply with the Dymally-Alatorre Bilingual Services Act, providing training materials in non-English languages. This section will be effective on July 1, 2017. This section of the act will be effective on July 1, 2017 and does not require reimbursement according to the California Constitution. The Legislature aims to establish the rights of child care providers in alternative payment programs to report violations to the State Department of Education. Section 8221.6 of the Education Code allows licensed or license-exempt child care providers receiving payment through alternative payment programs to file complaints for non-compliance with laws or regulations. This is done through the Uniform Complaint Procedures outlined in the California Code of Regulations. Alternative payment programs covered include the California Alternative Payment Program, CalWORKs Stage 2 Program, and CalWORKs Stage 3 Program. (b) Alternative payment programs are operated by contractors reimbursed under specific contract types: the California Alternative Payment Program, CalWORKs Stage 2 Program, CalWORKs Stage 3 Program, and the Migrant Alternative Payment Program. (c) The operation of this section is dependent on the appropriation of funds in the annual Budget Act or another statute.
